Expectation1: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation1: The task feeds directly into the next teammate’s work and delays would ripple.
Expectation2: Prepare sermons and deliver weekly messages during Shabbat services.
Situation2: It is time to begin brainstorming potential topics for a sermon several weeks from now.
Story: I sat at my desk, the glow of my computer screen illuminating the stack of project notes beside me. As a colleague, I knew the importance of meeting deadlines—my part of the report was due tomorrow, and any delay would stall the entire team. I could already picture the frustration on my teammate’s face if I missed the mark. Yet, as I glanced at my calendar, I saw a reminder: “Begin sermon prep.” As the rabbi, I was expected to offer thoughtful, relevant messages each Shabbat, and the congregation counted on me to bring insight and comfort. The pressure to start brainstorming weighed heavily; inspiration didn’t come on command, and I needed time to reflect and research. My mind tugged in two directions—one toward the immediate, tangible needs of my colleagues, the other toward the spiritual and emotional needs of my community. I felt the tension coil in my chest, knowing that whichever task I chose, I’d be letting someone down, or perhaps, letting myself down.
